chapter.title: 19 Specimen Collection, Transport, and Processing: Bacteriology*

sect1.title: 19 Specimen Collection, Transport, and Processing: Bacteriology*
sect1.para: The clinical microbiology laboratory is responsible for providing guidance on how to select, collect, label, and transport specimens for processing in the laboratory. This preanalytical phase of testing is critical for accurate laboratory resulting. It ensures the proper utilization of laboratory tests and the generation of results that are clinically significant and leads to improved patient outcomes. An improperly collected specimen can decrease the sensitivity of pathogen detection or introduce colonizing bacteria surrounding the site of infection, which complicates the laboratory workup of cultures and may result in unnecessary or inappropriate antimicrobial therapy. Such unnecessary therapy may in turn result in increased length of stay, additional costs, and potentially significant drug side effects (1).

Microbiologists must help health care providers to choose, collect, and transport the specimen in a manner that optimizes the laboratory’s diagnostic testing. To ensure high-quality results, microbiology laboratories should have clear procedures and policies on specimen acceptability and a system for rejecting inappropriate or insufficient specimens. One study showed that as many as 50% of inpatient laboratory tests ordered were inappropriate and not useful (2). Therefore, clinical microbiology laboratories must develop and enforce specimen management policies that promote careful specimen collection and processing and must be prepared to educate health care providers who try to override such policies. Examples include the testing of formed stool for Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile toxin and the collection of swab specimens when tissue or fluid could be obtained. More detailed information about sample handling and collection can be found in the Clinical Microbiology Procedures Handbook (3), and the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) and American Society for Microbiology (ASM) guidelines (4).

sect2.title: GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF SPECIMEN COLLECTION AND TRANSPORT
sect2.para: The preanalytical phase of microbial diagnosis involves (i) the collection of material from the site of suspected infection, (ii) proper timing for collection of specimens (preferably before the administration of antibiotics), (iii) optimal volume or quantity of specimen, (iv) use of appropriate collection devices and transport media, (v) proper labeling and maintenance of transport conditions, and (vi) a screening system to ensure that the specimen is acceptable for processing. General specimen selection and collection guidelines include proper labeling of the sample to include two patient identifiers, the source of the sample, and information on who collected the sample and at what time collection occurred.Table 1 summarizes collection and transport recommendations for routine bacteriology.

sect1.title: The Specimen Must Represent the Infected Site
sect1.para: The optimal specimen to be collected for laboratory diagnosis is based on the site of the infection and the nature of the suspected bacterium.Table 2 lists anatomic sites and corresponding appropriate and inappropriate clinical specimens (5).

sect1.title: Aspirates
sect1.para: For abscess contents, body fluids, and other fluid collections below the skin, aspirates obtained through disinfected intact skin are preferred. The skin should be thoroughly cleaned with chlorhexidine-alcohol or iodine-alcohol and allowed to completely dry before the needle is inserted. If anaerobes are being considered, the transport container must be free of air. Anaerobic transport vials with a nitrogen atmosphere above a gel containing oxygen-scavenging components are commercially available.

Normally sterile fluids, such as pleural, synovial, peritoneal, and pericardial fluids, should be sent to the laboratory in a capped syringe with the needle removed or placed in a sterile leak-proof cup for Gram staining and inoculation to culture media. Fluids should be concentrated using a Cytospin prior to Gram staining unless they are bloody or thick. If sufficient volume is received, recovery of clinically significant microorganisms can be improved by injecting up to 10 ml of sterile fluid (the inoculum volume should follow the manufacturer’s guidelines for the blood culture system) into an aerobic blood culture bottle (6).

sect1.title: Hardware and Prosthetic Devices
sect1.para: When prosthetic joint infection is suspected, at least 3 and optimally 5 or 6 periprosthetic tissue samples should be obtained for aerobic and anaerobic culture (7, 8). Isolation of the same species from at least 2 tissue samples from the infected site can help diagnose infection and differentiate contamination from true infection (8). However, prostheses may acquire a biofilm that promotes persistent infection that is difficult to diagnose by culture of joint fluid or tissue. Sonication of the prosthesis in a volume of liquid has been shown to increase sensitivity of detection of organisms over standard tissue culture (9). Sonication of implantable cardiac devices, such as pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators, has also been shown to improve sensitivity for detection of infection (10). In addition, sonication of other hardware, including spinal implants, has been described (11). For laboratories that lack specialized equipment for sonication of devices, a reasonable alternative is to add sterile saline to the device and vortex, followed by direct inoculation of the saline to culture medium. However, laboratories should continue to encourage providers to collect periprosthetic tissue for optimal diagnosis of infection associated with devices, including implantable cardiac devices (12).

sect1.title: Sputum
sect1.para: Expectorated sputum is the best noninvasive sample for diagnosis of pneumonia. The quality of sputa from patients other than those with cystic fibrosis should be evaluated microscopically for the presence of squamous epithelial cells (SECs), inflammatory cells, and bacteria (13, 14). To collect a high-quality sputum specimen, the patient should sit up, rinse out their mouth with water, and bring up a deep cough from the lungs. Sometimes mild percussion on the chest can help dislodge deep phlegm. If a patient cannot produce an acceptable sputum sample the first time, it is very unlikely that a repeat collection will yield a good specimen, and it is best to obtain an induced sputum. For noninvasive diagnosis of Legionella pneumonia, the use of urinary antigen tests is also recommended (15).

sect1.title: Stool
sect1.para: Rectal swabs and stool specimens have comparable sensitivities for detection of enteric pathogens from bacterial culture and molecular tests (16, 17). To collect a rectal swab, the swab should be inserted deep enough into the rectum to become visibly stained with stool. Many gastrointestinal stool pathogens are labile, so stool and rectal swabs should be submitted in transport media such as Cary-Blair or FecalSwab Cary-Blair (Copan, Murrieta, CA) to preserve viability of pathogens. Use of rectal swabs for molecular assays may require additional validation, as this is not an FDA-approved source.

Testing more than one stool for bacterial pathogens is rarely indicated (4). In adults, an enteric pathogen was detected in 87% of first stool samples, with a second sample increasing the positivity rate to 98% (18). In pediatric patients, an enteric pathogen was detected in 98% of first stool specimens (19). Diarrheal stool is loose and takes the shape of the container. Except for patients with documented ileus, formed stool should not be tested for C. difficile. In the general population, 4 to 15% of individuals are asymptomatic carriers of C. difficile, and testing carries the risk of an incorrect diagnosis and treatment (20). Children younger than 2 years are also frequently colonized with toxigenic C. difficile, and testing is not recommended (4) (see chapter 56, Clostridium and Clostridioides).

sect1.title: Swabs
sect1.para: Although swabs are easy to collect, they should be avoided when tissue, aspirate, or biopsy material is available (4). Swabs are prone to contamination by commensal microbiota and are particularly poor for recovery of mycobacteria and fungi. In particular, swabs from the surfaces of decubitus ulcers are not recommended for culture, as they are likely to yield colonizing bacteria that have superinfected the surface and the organisms recovered have poor correlation with those causing deep tissue or bone infection (21).

Swabs are generally preferred for collection of oropharyngeal samples, as it is technically easier to access the tonsils with a swab, and there are a limited number of media to inoculate. However, care should be taken to avoid touching noninvolved surfaces or mucosae, which harbor contaminating bacteria. Swabs are not recommended for diagnosis of sinusitis; aspirated material and tissue are preferred specimens. Endoscopically obtained swabs can recover bacterial pathogens but rarely detect fungi, which are common causes of chronic sinusitis (4).

However, new advances in swab technology have resulted in significant improvement on traditional swabs. Flocked swabs and E-swab transport systems (Copan, Murrieta, CA) have proven to be superior to wound swabs for the recovery of bacteria (22). The fibers of flocked swabs have numerous microscopic folds that are perpendicular to the shaft, significantly increasing the surface area and improving the amount of specimen that is collected. The E-swab transport tube consists of 1 ml of liquid medium such as Amies or Stuart’s medium, and when the flocked swab is placed in the liquid transport medium and vortexed, specimen is released from the swab fibers. In addition to aerobic bacteria, anaerobic bacteria can survive at least 48 h at room temperature or refrigerated (23). They also have the advantage of being compatible with automated front-end processing instruments (24). Improved elution of specimen material from the swab and the use of a larger liquid sample volume likely contribute to the improved bacterial recovery (24, 25).

sect1.title: Tissues
sect1.para: Tissue biopsy samples should be obtained by a surgeon using aseptic techniques. Surface skin should be disinfected with chlorhexidine-alcohol before the skin is cut. Once the first incision is made, which may inadvertently cut through a subsurface microcolony of commensal bacteria, the surgeon should switch to a fresh, sterile scalpel. Tissue should be placed into a sterile tube or cup with a tight lid. If anaerobes are considered likely, an anaerobic transport vial may be used to preserve anaerobe viability. Tissue from draining sinus lesions should be obtained by curetting deep within the interior of the tract after thorough surface skin disinfection. Swabs from the drainage are likely to harbor surface bacteria that may not be associated with the underlying infection and therefore should be avoided. Bone biopsy samples to diagnose osteomyelitis should be obtained directly from the bone itself after debridement of the overlying, usually superinfected tissue (26). Infected bone is soft enough to easily be removed by curetting or sometimes by aspiration with a large-bore needle.

sect1.title: Urine
sect1.para: Urine can be collected by midstream collection, catheterization (straight in-and-out or indwelling), cystoscopic collection, or suprapubic aspiration. Boric acid preservative or prompt refrigeration of urine should be used to prevent overgrowth of bacteria that occurs at room temperature (27). Foley catheter tips should not be submitted or accepted for culture, as they are always contaminated with members of the urethral microbiota and interpretation of results is not possible. Culture of pediatric bagged urine specimens, a plastic bag attached to the perineal region to collect urine from children too young to produce a midstream urine sample, should be discouraged for the same reason (28).

sect1.title: Volume and Size of Sample
sect1.para: In general, the more material available for testing, the better. This is true especially when more than one type of culture is requested. However, receiving more than the necessary specimen volume or size to accommodate all requests can also be problematic. Health care providers should not send large bags of fluids, except in the case of peritoneal dialysate (from which the laboratory staff should remove 50 ml to concentrate by centrifugation), or very large pieces of tissue such as bone. Large specimens require more manipulation in the laboratory than necessary, which can introduce contaminants or result in a less productive part of the sample being selected for testing. When possible, at least 1 ml of fluid and 1 g or 1 cm3 of tissue should be submitted for Gram staining and routine bacterial culture; more may be necessary for additional studies (29). If the volume received is not sufficient to perform all requests or to inoculate all the usual media, the physician should be contacted to prioritize the requests. This not only helps the microbiologist to perform the appropriate test but also alerts the physician that the sample was problematic and could serve to motivate collection of adequate specimens in the future. Suggested blood volumes are described in the section on blood cultures (also see Table 6).

sect1.title: Specimen Transport
sect1.para: The type of test to be performed determines the nature of the transport system. The performance of various swab types and transport media should be verified prior to implementation. Manufacturers are required to do this, and laboratories also perform verifications of transport devices. For example, some nonviable bacteria in transport media (allowed per U.S. Food and Drug Administration [FDA] specifications) may be seen in initial Gram stains of specimens received in anaerobic transport media, so microbiologists may wish to sample several lots of the product to ascertain a low burden of dead but stainable organisms. The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute has developed standards for evaluating transport devices (30). Table 1 summarizes transport recommendations for routine bacteriology.

listitem.para: Transport specimens to the laboratory as soon as possible after collection. For most specimens, if transport will require more than 2 h, either a specific transport medium or refrigeration is required (Table 1). For samples to be tested by molecular methods only, refrigeration or even freezing (−80°C is best) is acceptable. The manufacturer’s recommended or companion transport materials must be used for commercial molecular assays. Any deviation from the product insert in sample collection and handling for any in vitro diagnostic test requires the laboratory to perform a verification of the performance of the assay.
Inoculate bacterial culture media within 24 h even if appropriate transport medium or refrigeration is maintained.

Small volumes of fluid (≤1 ml) or tissue (≤1 cm3) should be submitted within 15 to 30 min to avoid evaporation, drying, and exposure to ambient conditions. A few drops of nonbacteriostatic saline may be added for hydration. Larger volumes and specimens in appropriate transport medium may be stored for as long as 24 h.

Bacteria that are especially sensitive to ambient conditions includeShigella spp., Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Bordetella pertussis, and anaerobes. Reliable detection of these species requires rapid processing. Delays of up to 6 h result in some loss of CFU even when transport media are used (30–32). Longer delays result in significant loss of organisms. For delays beyond 6 h, refrigeration improves recovery (30).

Moving clinical specimens from one laboratory to another, regardless of the distance and vehicle used, requires adherence to specimen packaging and labeling instructions mandated by the federal government. Materials for transport must be labeled properly, packaged to enable absorption and containment of any liquid released during a break or spill, and protected during transport. See the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) website (http://www.cdc.gov/od/eaipp/shipping/) and the International Air Transport Association (http://www.iata.org/publications/dgr/pages/index.aspx) for more information.

For detection of selected fastidious organisms, the laboratory should provide clear instructions for transport methods (33). If specimens are to be shipped to a distant reference laboratory, the reference laboratory’s conditions and requests must be met, and in many instances, the laboratory provides transport devices to users. Continuous dialogue with health care providers ensures that the appropriate information on collection and transport is accessed before specimen collection begins.

sect2.title: HANDLING OF SPECIMENS IN THE LABORATORY

sect1.title: Documentation of Arrival, Condition, and Appropriate Sample for Test Ordered
sect1.para: Upon arrival of specimens in the laboratory, the time and date of receipt should be recorded. All specimens and requisitions should be carefully inspected. Specimens must be correctly labeled and, if accompanied by a requisition form, contain at least two patient identifiers. The requisition form must include the patient’s name, age, sex, identifying number (such as medical record number or unique registration/billing number), ordering location (hospital location, physician’s office address, etc.), the ordering physician’s name; the specimen source (detailed), the date and time of collection, and the test ordered. If an electronic laboratory system is used, all of the relevant information mentioned in this section is usually captured. If a specimen is mislabeled or no patient name is provided, the specimen should be rejected and another specimen should be collected. If another specimen cannot be collected (for example, tissue collected during a surgical procedure), the physician or nurse should be contacted and personally identify the specimen. When relabeling has occurred, the course of events must be outlined in the laboratory report so that the physician interpreting the results is aware of potential errors. Each specimen processed in the laboratory should receive a unique laboratory accession number. Subsequently, the time of plating, which may differ substantially from the time of receipt, should be recorded.

sect1.title: Specimen Rejection
sect1.para: Some specimen collection sites, transport containers, or transport conditions render the specimen unacceptable for processing (34). Table 1 lists acceptable criteria for specimen management based on collection or transport conditions and times. When specimens fall outside these limits (too long in transit, incorrect temperature, not in proper transport medium, wrong site for requested test, etc.), new specimens should be collected whenever possible. Table 3 lists unacceptable specimen types for anaerobic culture requests that should be rejected. Major reasons for rejection include inappropriate transport conditions, poor quality of specimen material collected, and inappropriate specimen type for the test requested (Tables 3 and 4).

Specimens are rejected by contacting the patient’s health care provider, explaining the reason for rejection, and requesting a replacement specimen of acceptable quality. Timely notification and collection of replacement specimens are necessary, especially in instances where antimicrobial therapy has been initiated. Specimen rejection criteria should be reviewed by appropriate laboratory and medical staff representatives before becoming policy. Specimens determined to have gross bacterial contamination by members of the microbiota, such as sputum specimens with an abundance of SECs seen on initial Gram stain, should be rejected.

sect1.title: Handling Samples That Are To Be Processed at a Remote Site
sect1.para: Transport and processing time limits suitable for laboratories near the specimen collection site are not appropriate for remote laboratories. Specimens must be handled in the same manner regardless of whether they are to be transported via public or private mail service. See the CDC Office of Health and Safety site and the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration site (https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/training/hazmat/transporting-infectious-substances-safely) for the latest guidelines. Managing movement of specimens using temperature-controlled boxes, reliable courier service, and good tracking systems remains a challenge for many providers.

sect1.title: Prioritization
sect1.para: For busy laboratories that receive many samples over a short period, it is helpful to develop a priority list to assist accessioning staff in determining the order in which samples should be processed (3, 34). Gram staining of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), positive blood culture broth, surgical specimens, and sterile body fluid specimens should receive the highest priority.

sect1.title: Initial Sample Handling

listitem.para: Swabs should be inoculated onto medium plates, with the least inhibitory medium being inoculated first. For flocked swabs in liquid media, the specimen should be mixed by vortexing; either application of specimen using the swab or drops of the suspension can be used to prepare the slide and inoculate media.
Sputum is best sampled from the container with wooden sticks, which do not absorb the fluid sections but stick to the more purulent portions, where the pathogens are likely to be.

Clear fluids other than urine should be concentrated on a slide using a cytocentrifuge. If a cytocentrifuge is not available, samples of ≥1 ml should be centrifuged (1,500 ×g for 15 min) and the supernatant removed with a pipette down to 1.0 ml (35). This sediment is mixed thoroughly (vortex or pipette) and used for testing. If the material is thick, bloody, or frank pus, it should be applied to the slide without concentration and smeared thinly, similar to making a thin blood film.

Tissue and bone for bacteriology cultures should be ground in a mortar and pestle, or tissue may be dispersed in an automated stomacher (Seward Limited, Worthing, West Sussex, United Kingdom). A drop of this suspension should be struck to obtain isolated colonies. If fungal cultures are requested, tissue and bone should be minced (not ground) using a sterile scalpel and a small piece of intact tissue inoculated into the surface of each agar medium to preserve the viability of members of theMucorales.

A Gram stain should be examined for all fluids and tissues and some swabs, such as those received for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Table 5). Gram stains can deliver rapid, actionable results to clinicians, can determine if a specimen is acceptable for culture based on cellularity, and should be used to aid the microbiologist in interpretation of the culture (34). Infection gives rise to purulence (abundant polymorphonuclear cells), blood, necrosis, and mucus (mucous membrane specimens). In general, gross examination of the specimen should identify yellow to tan purulence, red to rust-colored blood, clear and tenacious mucus, and brown to black discoloration of necrotic tissue. Portions for smear and culture should be taken from these areas. Ideally, microscopic examination of smears, using a 10× microscope objective, should demonstrate many polymorphonuclear cells (PMNs) and few or no SECs, which would suggest cutaneous or mucocutaneous contamination with members of the normal bacterial microbiota (Fig. 1 and 2).

Based on the site of the sample and physicians’ requests, each specimen should be inoculated to an appropriate medium chosen to recover suspected pathogens (Table 5). In this era of diminishing resources, two relatively recent innovations improve this process: chromogenic agars and automated plate inoculators. Chromogenic agars produce colonies that can be identified to genus or species level directly from the appearance of the colonies without any further testing. Not only are they available for urinary tract pathogens (36) and some stool pathogens (37), but they are also widely used for screening samples for resistant bacteria, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), and multidrug-resistant Gram-negative rods (38, 39). In some cases, they may be cost-effective by virtue of reducing both time and reagents used to identify the organisms compared to the conventional manner.

sect1.para: Several automated medium inoculators are commercially available that, in general, perform at least as well as manual plating and reduce workload for short-staffed laboratories (40). Some require that the sample be inoculated onto the plate, while others handle the container containing any liquid specimen, including E-swabs (41). These instruments are being adopted with increasing frequency as laboratory staffing becomes leaner.

Enrichment broth should be used only when appropriate (Table 5). For samples such as superficial swabs, broth cultures are more likely to yield contaminating members of the skin microbiota than pathogens (42). When fastidious species or organisms may be present in small numbers, such as with cardiac valves, the use of enrichment broths may be warranted. When simultaneously inoculated plates yield growth, it is rarely useful or efficient to continue to work with the broth. When initial plates do not show growth in the face of a sample with PMNs or other suggestions of an infectious process, subculture of the enrichment broth may be informative. Growth of skin organisms such as coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, Propionibacterium, and Cutibacterium species must be evaluated in concert with clinical criteria to avoid overinterpretation (43).

sect1.para: Once inoculated to the appropriate media based on the laboratory’s protocols (Table 5), plates and broths are incubated in the appropriate atmosphere before they are examined for growth. Chocolate plates are always incubated in 5% CO2, blood may be incubated in either air or CO2 (depending on the requirements of the organisms to be recovered), and selective agar plates are best incubated in air. Special incubation atmospheres, such as microaerophilic conditions, are mentioned in the chapters covering the species that require them. Unless otherwise noted, ideal temperatures for bacterial growth are 35 to 37°C.

Specimens for anaerobic culture should be processed as soon as possible after arrival in the laboratory. Usual media can include an anaerobic blood agar plate (CDC blood agar or brucella blood agar), a medium that inhibits Gram-positive and facultative Gram-negative bacilli (such as KV [kanamycin-vancomycin] blood agar), a differential or selective medium (such as bacteroides bile esculin), a Gram-positive selective medium (colistin-nalidixic acid blood agar or phenylethyl alcohol blood agar), and an enrichment broth (such as chopped meat carbohydrate or thioglycolate) (Table 5). Media should be incubated in an anaerobic environment immediately after inoculation (see chapter 53, Approach to Identification of Anaerobic Bacteria).

listitem.para: For many reasons, it is best to retain specimens, including empty containers if the entire specimen was used. Sometimes additional tests are requested after other results, such as histopathology, become available. Sometimes there is an error during laboratory processing and the original aliquot must be resampled. Other reasons include the need to check the label on the specimen, to prepare a second smear if there is a question on interpretation of the first one, or to examine the gross appearance of the sample. If possible, specimens should be stored in a refrigerator or ultracold freezer for a minimum of 5 days.

sect1.title: Specimen Transport for Molecular Detection of Bacteria
sect1.para: Recommended procedures and transport systems for molecular detection of bacteria vary depending on the test system employed. Fresh stool or stool collected in Cary-Blair transport medium is suitable for testing using multiplex gastrointestinal panels and molecular assays forC. difficile. Tissue is sometimes submitted for detection of bacterial pathogens using molecular amplification or DNA sequencing and should be collected aseptically in a sterile container. For commercial or specialized molecular tests, the transport system should be specific for the type of test. Recent IDSA/ASM guidelines address these issues (4). Special swabs with proprietary transport medium or first-void urine specimens (≤30 ml) are often required for molecular detection of N. gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

sect2.title: LABORATORY SAFETY ISSUES REGARDING BACTERIAL PATHOGENS
sect2.para: Laboratory personnel should always maintain a level of suspicion that any specimen could harbor a highly infectious agent. Physicians should be educated to alert the laboratory when they suspect the possibility of any pathogen associated with laboratory-acquired infections, includingCoccidioides immitis-Coccidioides posadasii, Brucella, and Francisella tularensis (44). Laboratorians should obtain recommended vaccines, including those against N. meningitidis and other pathogens if the laboratory is expected to encounter them. All specimen processing should be performed in a biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) cabinet to prevent contamination of specimens, and staff should wear personal protective equipment, including a splash-proof gown and gloves, to minimize accidental exposures. Any laboratorians who process specimens that could generate aerosols or who might have to enter an environment where aerosols are possible must be fit tested for an N95 mask or similar protective face shield respirator. These masks should be worn in any situation where aerosols are possible. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration mandates the Respiratory Protection Standard specifically for potential tuberculosis or severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus exposures, but other regulatory agencies and most employers have extended these rules to other respiratory hazards (https://www.osha.gov/SLTC/respiratoryprotection/standards.html). The CDC’s most recent biosafety manual, found at http://www.cdc.gov/biosafety/publications/bmbl5/bmbl.pdf, has guidelines for research and clinical laboratories. A CDC-produced article in Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report provides additional information about safety in clinical laboratories (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/su6101a1.htm). Chapter 14 (Prevention of Laboratory-Acquired Infections) contains a more in-depth discussion of biosafety in the laboratory.

sect1.title: Engineering Controls
sect1.para: Laboratory environments should be designed to protect workers from biohazards inherent in the nature of the work. Ready access to properly maintained and certified BSL-2 laminar-flow biological cabinets and good training in the proper use of such equipment are important (seechapter 14, Prevention of Laboratory-Acquired Infections). When BSL-2 cabinets are not available, all manipulations that may result in aerosol formation and those involving samples containing blood or body fluids (such as procedures involving blood culture bottles) should be performed behind a Plexiglas or other clear shield. Specimen containers should be carried within the laboratory in trays with solid sides and bottoms to prevent spillage if dropped accidentally. Plates that are suspected to harbor growth of any dangerous pathogen should be taped on both sides to allow circulation of atmosphere but not allow accidental opening. All laboratory workers should know what to do in the event of a spill or accidental release in the laboratory, and drills should be conducted periodically to reinforce proper responses.

sect2.title: SPECIFIC SPECIMEN COLLECTION AND PROCESSING RECOMMENDATIONS (ALSO SEE TABLE 7)

sect1.title: Autopsy Samples
sect1.para: Microbiology testing as a component of the autopsy examination has been controversial (45). Postmortem and agonal invasion of sterile tissues confuses the significance of positive culture results, prompting some to argue against microbiology testing. Others found that postmortem examination continues to uncover a significant number of diagnoses of infectious diseases (45). To minimize contamination of postmortem specimens, the body should be moved to a refrigerated locker (4 to 6°C) as soon as possible after death, and specimens should be collected from refrigerated bodies within 15 h of death. This serves to diminish the likelihood of postmortem overgrowth of contaminants and improve detection of true pathogens.

Specimens should be obtained by sterilizing the surface of the organ with a hot spatula or iron surface until the surface is thoroughly dry. Body fluids, including blood, should be collected first. For blood collection, the wall of the heart and large vessel should be seared and a sterile needle (18 to 20 gauge) inserted. A 20-ml volume should be collected and injected directly into aerobic and anaerobic blood culture bottles. Solid viscera should be sampled by immediately cutting blocks of tissue from the center of the seared area. Samples should be submitted to the microbiology laboratory in sterile containers with a requisition providing a full explanation of the studies needed. Tissue samples should be processed following standard laboratory methods, and tests should include Gram staining and culture.

sect1.title: Blood Cultures
sect1.para: Detection of bacteria and fungi circulating in the bloodstream is a major function of the microbiology laboratory (46, 47). A very important factor in obtaining optimal samples is reducing the potential for contamination by thorough disinfection of the skin surface. An appropriate goal for the blood culture contamination rate is ≤3%, though with implementation of all recommended best practices, a 1% contamination rate should be achievable (48). Blood draws through an indwelling intravenous line should generally be avoided, as blood obtained in this way is more than twice as likely to contain a surface organism contaminant as is blood obtained through a peripheral skin site (49). As many as 26% of all positive blood cultures are likely to represent contamination and are associated with unnecessary expense, increased length of hospitalization, and dangers of antimicrobial misuse (49). Common contaminants include coagulase-negative staphylococci, Micrococcus spp., Corynebacterium spp., Bacillus spp., viridans group streptococci, and Cutibacterium acnes (48). In general, single cultures positive for these bacteria reflect contamination. Multiple, separate cultures growing the same strain of these organisms are more likely to indicate a clinically significant bacteremia. Careful site cleansing, using either chlorhexidine-alcohol or iodine tincture, is critical to avoid contaminants (50, 51). All skin disinfectants are activated as they go from wet to dry on the skin surface, so a waiting period of 30 s (chlorhexidine and iodine tincture) is necessary before the needle is inserted. New products are now available that allow diversion and discard of the first few milliliters of blood, which are likely to contain skin contaminants, but more data are needed to support the recommendation that a discard is needed (48).

Another important factor to aid the interpretation of blood culture results is obtaining two separate blood culture sets from two separate sites. Skin commensals involved in true sepsis should be recovered from both sets. Most hospital laboratories have a standard policy that blood culture orders always involve obtaining blood from two separate sites, each inoculating at least two separate bottles. Recovery of all organisms, obligate anaerobes as well as most aerobic bacteria, is enhanced if two types of medium are used. Most often, laboratories choose one aerobic and one anaerobic broth bottle (composing 1 blood culture set). For children, an anaerobic broth bottle is usually not employed unless the patient is at risk for anaerobic septicemia (52). Total volume of blood cultured is the major factor for identifying true-positive patients. For an adult, the most sensitive recovery requires at least 40 ml of blood (2 blood culture sets) (53). This is a small percentage of total blood volume. Yields from 20 ml and 30 ml of blood were 29.8% and 47.2% greater, respectively, than those from 10 ml of blood; yields from 40 ml were 7.2% greater than those from 30 ml (53). Table 6 shows recommended blood culture volumes for pediatric patients, based on the weight of the patient and the corresponding percentage of the patient’s total blood volume (4). Blood should be collected as quickly as possible after the culture is ordered and before antibiotics are given. In most cases, timing of the blood culture with respect to the maximum temperature recorded for the patient during a febrile episode is less important than total volume cultured (54).

For automated blood culture systems, the standard 5-day protocol is sufficient to recover all the usual pathogens and some unusual ones, such as the HACEK organisms (Haemophilus spp. Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella spp.), and holding bottles for additional incubation time only increases the numbers of contaminants recovered (55, 56). Sodium polyanethol sulfonate, used in all blood culture systems as an anticoagulant, may be inhibitory to N. meningitidis, N. gonorrhoeae, Peptostreptococcus anaerobius, Streptobacillus moniliformis, and Gardnerella vaginalis, but the collection of an appropriate ratio of blood to broth volume dilutes sodium polyanethol sulfonate, thereby helping to reduce the inhibitory effect (57). In addition, if fungemia due to yeast is suspected, inoculation of blood in standard aerobic blood culture bottle is usually sufficient (see chapter 118, Specimen Collection, Transport and Processing: Mycology). Positive blood culture bottles are evaluated initially by examining a Gram-stained smear of the broth. The report should include a description of the bacterial morphology and the Gram stain reaction. Specimens in positive blood culture bottles should be subcultured to media based on the organism seen in the Gram-stained smear. In general, this should include sheep blood agar, chocolate agar, MacConkey agar, and Columbia nalidixic acid agar plates, since 5 to 10% of all bacteremias are polymicrobial. Anaerobic media and culture conditions should be used if the morphology of the organism seen in the Gram-stained smear is suggestive of an anaerobic bacterium or if the organism is recovered from an anaerobic culture bottle only. If a positively flagged bottle shows no organisms on Gram stain, a second smear should be prepared and stained using acridine orange, a DNA stain (58). If organisms are present, even if they have damaged or no cell walls, they will stain bright orange and can be recognized more easily.

Rapid sample preparation and improvements in matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry databases have made identification of organisms from positive blood cultures by mass spectrometry more feasible for clinical laboratories (59, 60). In addition, a number of nucleic acid amplification and/or hybridization assays, performed directly from positive blood cultures, are now commercially available. These assays dramatically shorten the time to identification result reporting and have been shown to decrease time to effective antibiotic therapy, length of stay, and hospital costs (61, 62). Details on these rapid molecular and proteomic methods are reviewed in chapter 5, Laboratory Detection of Bacteremia and Fungemia.

sect2.title: Role of Follow-up Blood Cultures after Initial Positivity
sect2.para: The Infectious Disease Society of America guidelines for the treatment of methicillin-resistantS. aureus (MRSA) bacteremia recommend repeating blood cultures to document clearance of infection 2 to 4 days after the initial positive culture (63). A single set of surveillance blood cultures is adequate to document clearance in individuals with S. aureus bacteremia. Staphylococcus lugdunensis is equally virulent and associated with infective endocarditis, so a similar approach is reasonable. Patients with Gram-negative bacteremia rarely have persistent bacteremia when source control is adequate and do not require routine follow-up blood cultures (64).

sect1.title: Central Venous Catheters
sect1.para: Traditional methods for culture of intravascular catheter tips are controversial for determining the source of a bacteremia, because by the time the culture result is obtained, the catheter (if it was the source) has already been removed (65). The most common technique used to culture the exterior of the intravascular portion of a catheter is the semiquantitative method in which the 5-cm distal portion of the catheter is rolled across a blood agar plate four times (66). Growth of ≥15 colonies is considered significant, i.e., implicating the catheter tip as the likely source of a bacteremia caused by the same organism simultaneously isolated from blood cultures. Interpretation of clinical importance is not possible without an accompanying positive blood culture. For suspected catheter exit site infection, freshly expressed pus can be aspirated for culture.

Some laboratories have adopted methods for determining if the indwelling intravenous (usually central) line is the source of a bacteremia without removing the line. One method requires a 3-fold-higher quantity of organisms recovered in the blood obtained through the line than that obtained peripherally. However, determining CFU is labor-intensive, so an alternative method uses the differential time to positivity, where a blood culture drawn from a central line signals positive at least 2 h earlier than the peripheral blood culture (66). Neither catheter tip surface cultures nor differential time-to-positivity methods appear to work well in predicting catheter-related candidemia (67).

sect1.title: Cerebrospinal Fluid
sect1.para: CSF is collected by lumbar puncture for the diagnosis of meningitis (Table 7). As with all clinical specimens, even those collected from a presumably sterile site, growth of contaminants occasionally does occur. The first tube collected by lumbar puncture, which is most likely to have a few skin organisms introduced during the procedure, should be used for chemistry tests; the second or third tube, which is less likely to contain the rare contaminant, should be used for microbiology studies (68).

Although bacterial staining and culture can be performed with as little as 0.5 ml of CSF, larger volumes are preferred. If the specimen volume is less than required for multiple requested tests, providers should be contacted to prioritize testing. Specimens should be delivered rapidly in a sterile container maintained at room temperature. All smears should be prepared by cytocentrifugation, and cultures should be inoculated with 0.5 ml of CSF (69). Media are inoculated in accordance with recommendations in Table 5. Larger CSF volumes, 7 to 10 ml, are recommended for recovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, although the yield may still be low (70). As a result, the use of nucleic acid tests is recommended by the World Health Organization for diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis, although none of these tests are approved by the FDA for this purpose (71, 72). Anaerobes are rarely found in CSF, even in cases of mixed anaerobic abscess of brain tissue. C. acnes may be the cause of infection in patients with indwelling CSF shunts; hence the recommendation to perform anaerobic culture on shunt specimens (73, 74).

Smears should be Gram stained and results reported to the physician immediately. Results should include a description and semiquantitative enumeration of polymorphonuclear inflammatory cells and bacterial morphology. Because of low sensitivity and lack of effect on the care and management of patients, direct antigen tests for bacteria are not recommended. Note that cryptococcal antigen tests are still valuable. A multiplex PCR panel for the simultaneous detection of 14 bacterial, viral, and yeast pathogens in about an hour from 200 μl of CSF is commercially available (FilmArray ME panel; BioFire Diagnostics, Salt Lake City, UT), but molecular detection should not replace bacterial culture (75).

sect1.title: Eyes
sect1.para: Several types of specimens may be collected for the microbiological analysis of eye infections, including conjunctival scrapings obtained with a swab or sterile spatula for the diagnosis of conjunctivitis, corneal scrapings collected with a sterile spatula for the diagnosis of keratitis, vitreous fluid collected by aspiration for the diagnosis of endophthalmitis, and fluid material collected by aspiration or tissue biopsy for the diagnosis of periorbital cellulitis. Pathogenic bacteria potentially present in these anatomic sites are listed inTable 7. Because the volume of specimen collected from corneal scrapings and vitreous fluid aspiration is very small, direct inoculation of agar culture plates and preparation of smears in the clinic or at the bedside are recommended. A close working association is needed between the laboratory and ophthalmologist to ensure a supply of appropriate culture media, correct technique for inoculation of media, and rapid transport of plates and smears to the laboratory. Media should be inoculated by rubbing the specimen onto a small area of the agar plates or wiping the material from the scraping off the spatula gently onto the agar surface, sometimes in the shapes of little Cs. Plates are often labeled OD (right eye) or OS (left eye) and should be placed directly in the incubator without cross-streaking by laboratory personnel.

bDisease caused by ingestion of preformed toxin.
cC. diphtheriae, M. tuberculosis, F. tularensis, T. pallidum, B. henselae (cat scratch), P. multocida, Bacillus thuringiensis, and Moraxella lacunata.

Media needed for the detection of usual pathogens include chocolate agar for fastidious bacteria and most fungi (Table 5) (76). Cultures for other microorganisms (some fungi, viruses, mycobacteria, etc.) should be inoculated if deemed appropriate by the ophthalmologist and microbiologist and specifically ordered. Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are the test of choice for detection of C. trachomatis in conjunctival scrapings for the diagnosis of inclusion conjunctivitis or trachoma, but they require in-house verification, as none of the commercially available assays are FDA approved for ocular specimens (77). If a C. trachomatis NAAT is not available for ocular specimens, conjunctival scrapings and secretions should be transported in viral/chlamydia transport medium (such as M4, M5, or M6) for culture (see chapter 66, Chlamydia).

sect1.title: Ears
sect1.para: Nasopharyngeal culture results are poor predictors of middle ear pathogens and should not be used for that purpose (78). Two types of ear specimens are received most commonly by the laboratory: swab specimens for the diagnosis of otitis externa and middle ear fluid specimens for the diagnosis of otitis media (Table 7). Potential pathogens at these two sites differ (79). Anaerobic culture, if ordered for middle ear fluid, should be performed on properly collected aspirates that are transported in anaerobic transport vials. Direct examination of Gram-stained smears of middle ear fluid is helpful and is recommended with all culture requests.

sect1.title: Gastrointestinal Tract
sect1.para: Stool specimens are frequently submitted to the microbiology laboratory to determine the etiological agent of infectious diarrhea. In fact, most diarrhea is caused not by bacteria but by viruses, parasites, immune-related disease, or other factors. Feces submitted for detection of enteric pathogens should be collected in a clean container with a tight lid and should not be contaminated with urine, barium, or toilet paper. Because intestinal pathogens can be killed by the metabolism of other fecal bacteria rapidly acidifying the specimen, specimens should be transferred to Cary-Blair transport medium soon after collection.Shigella is the most labile, often becoming unculturable within 30 min of collection. For Vibrio cholerae, other transport media, such as alkaline peptone water, are preferred. Rectal swabs have been shown to have sensitivity for fecal pathogen detection similar to that of stool for both culture and molecular detection (16, 17).

Use of a fecal collection and transport device consisting of a flocked swab in 2 ml of modified Cary-Blair medium can also be considered (80). The use of culture-independent diagnostic tests, such as NAATs, for a panel of stool pathogens has become more common (81).

It should be standard practice in all laboratories to evaluate the appropriateness of stool culture or NAAT requests. Hospitalized patients who did not enter the hospital with diarrhea are unlikely to develop bacterial enterocolitis caused by bacterial agents other thanC. difficile (82–84). For this reason, stool samples from patients who have been hospitalized for more than 3 days should be rejected. C. difficile testing in the hospital setting should be performed only on liquid stools and in conjunction with infection control policies. The goal is to maximize detection of C. difficile infection and minimize detection of colonized individuals. C. difficile infection is rapidly expanding as a community-acquired disease, and requests for C. difficile infection testing on liquid stools should not be rejected when ordered for outpatients (84). After an initial negative NAAT for C. difficile, however, repeat testing is not warranted, and use of NAATs for test of cure is inappropriate (84) (see chapter 56, Clostridium and Clostridioides).

Numerous studies have shown that neither fecal leukocyte examination nor lactoferrin is useful for differentiating inflammatory from noninflammatory diarrhea (85). For these reasons, use of any tests for fecal leukocytes should not be relied on to rule in or rule out acute infectious diarrhea. Usual gastrointestinal pathogens are listed in Table 7, and selective and differential media used to detect Salmonella, Shigella and Campylobacter spp. are listed in Table 5. Media for isolation of Campylobacter spp. are incubated at 42°C in a microaerophilic atmosphere of nitrogen (85%), carbon dioxide (10%), and oxygen (5%) for up to 3 days. All other agar plates should be incubated in air at 35 to 37°C for 2 days before being reported as negative. Testing for less frequently encountered pathogens should be considered when epidemiological factors suggest an increased likelihood. This may require periodic surveys of one’s community to establish which pathogens are most common, especially when the addition of selective medium or a toxin assay for the routine detection of campylobacters other than Campylobacter jejuni or Campylobacter coli, Vibrio spp., and Yersinia enterocolitica is being considered. Rapid enzyme immunoassay (EIA) methods for detection of surface antigens of some Campylobacter species have been evaluated and shown to be sensitive but have poor positive predictive value and should not be used as stand-alone tests (82). Culture-independent diagnostic tests, such as NAATs, demonstrate excellent sensitivity and specificity for detection of Campylobacter spp. and offer the advantage of simultaneous and rapid detection of other enteric pathogens (81).

sect2.title: Shiga-Toxin Producing Escherichia coli
sect2.para: Shiga toxin-producingEscherichia coli (STEC) causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic-uremic syndrome. The prevalence of STEC varies in different parts of the United States and the rest of the world. In addition to E. coli O157:H7, there are many other serotypes of STEC. In fact, in the United States, ~50% of STEC organisms are not serotype O157:H7 (86, 87). Shiga toxin EIAs and NAAT panels detect all serotypes. Routine culture of all stools on a selective medium and use of either an EIA or NAAT on an enriched broth (either Gram-negative broth or MacConkey broth) for detection of STEC have been recommended by the CDC (88). Recommendations from both the CDC and American Public Health Laboratory for universal STEC testing contain strategies for referral of non-O157 strains for further testing by public health laboratories (89). A downloadable guide is available from the American Public Health Laboratory site (http://www.aphl.org/AboutAPHL/publications/Documents/FS_2012April_Guidance-for-PHLs-Isolation-and-Characterization-of-Shiga-Toxin-Producing-Escherichia-coli-STEC-from-Clinical.pdf). Sorbitol-MacConkey agar, cefixime-tellurite-sorbitol-MacConkey agar, or a chromogenic agar can be used to detect O157 serotype strains. Non-O157 strains, such as the European outbreak O104 strain, will not be detected using these media (90).

sect2.title: Other Enteric Pathogens
sect2.para: Routine testing forVibrio spp., Y. enterocolitica, Aeromonas spp., and Plesiomonas shigelloides should not be performed in some geographic locations, since incidences are so low in most parts of the United States that the routine use of selective media is not justified. Testing should be available in house or through a reference laboratory upon provider request or in certain epidemiological situations. Media used for these enteric pathogens include thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose agar for vibrios, cefsulodin-Irgasan-novobiocin agar for Y. enterocolitica, and blood agar or selective blood agar to demonstrate hemolysis and provide a medium for oxidase testing for Aeromonas spp. and P. shigelloides (both oxidase positive) (82). All of these enteric pathogens grow on usual media, but detection is enhanced and simplified using specific selective media.

sect2.title: Detection of VRE, CRE, or Beta-Hemolytic Streptococci in Rectal Specimens
sect2.para: Identifying carriers of VRE and/or carbapenem-producing carbapenem-resistantEnterobacterales (CP-CRE) for infection control purposes and group A streptococci during investigations of nosocomial outbreaks or for diagnosis of perianal infections in children, respectively, requires collection of a rectal swab specimen (91). Carriers of VRE can be identified by culturing rectal swabbed or perirectal swabbed material or by the use of molecular methods. Swab specimens are inoculated to selective enrichment broth, such as Enterococcosel broth with 6 μg of vancomycin/ml, colistin-nalidixic acid blood agar containing 6 μg of vancomycin/ml, or VRE chromogenic agar. Detection of CP-CRE carriage can also be performed using either molecular or culture-based approaches. Culture of CP-CRE often relies on the use of selective screening plates or chromogenic agar, with or without enrichment broth, while a variety of molecular diagnostic approaches have been described (92). Additional resources for surveillance of VRE and CP-CRE are available on the CDC website at https://www.cdc.gov/hai/settings/lab/lab_settings.html. Group A streptococci can be isolated by culturing rectal swab specimens on sheep blood agar or selective streptococcal agars.

sect1.title: Genital Samples
sect1.para: Bacterial infections of genital tract sites produce various clinical syndromes, including vulvovaginitis, BV, genital ulcers, urethritis, cervicitis, endometritis, salpingitis, and ovarian abscess in females and urethritis, epididymitis, prostatitis, and genital ulcers in males. These diseases and their etiologies are listed inTable 7.

sect2.title: Detection of N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis
sect2.para: NAAT methods are preferred for detection ofN. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis in endocervical, vaginal, urethral, and urine specimens. Users must pay close attention to the types of specimens approved for use with each commercial assay. Specimens should be collected using the procedures and devices recommended by the manufacturer. Of note, recent publications using NAATs have highlighted greater prevalence of Trichomonas than chlamydia and gonorrhea in certain patient populations, leading to a growing trend towards simultaneous screening for Trichomonas, chlamydia, and gonorrhea (93). In addition, NAATs for Mycoplasma genitalium are also now available and recommended for males with recurrent nongonococcal urethritis and women with recurrent cervicitis (94).

Extragenital screening increases the rate ofChlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae detection for both adult and pediatric patients (94, 95). Although eye, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens are not always FDA cleared for testing in the commercial amplification systems, molecular methods are superior to culture (96). In addition, due to the high sensitivity of molecular tests, self-collected swabs from both men and women perform at least as well as those collected by health care personnel for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae (97, 98). In some jurisdictions, culture is still the only acceptable diagnostic procedure for medical legal cases, but due to the low sensitivity of C. trachomatis culture, a NAAT should always be performed for medical decisions (4).

Culture forN. gonorrhoeae is optimal when the specimen is directly inoculated in the physician’s office to a selective medium, such as modified Thayer-Martin medium, and incubated immediately, followed by transport to the clinical laboratory. Alternatively, swab specimens should be placed in a transport system containing Stuart’s or Amies medium and delivered to the microbiology laboratory as quickly as possible. Cotton swabs should be avoided, because they may be toxic to N. gonorrhoeae. Some newer transport products have shown improved ability to retain the viability of N. gonorrhoeae (99, 100). Specimens for N. gonorrhoeae culture should be held at refrigeration temperature during transport (101).

sect2.title: Bacterial vaginosis (BV)
sect2.para: BV occurs when conditions result in overgrowth of usual vaginal microbiota with various anaerobic organisms, includingG. vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides (102). Diagnosis is best made using the Gram stain and interpreted with a standardized scoring system, such as the Nugent score (103). Routine culture of vaginal specimens for diagnosis of BV is not recommended, as G. vaginalis is a part of the vaginal microbiota. A variety of non-culture-based assays using hybridization or NAAT are commercially available for the simultaneous detection of BV, Candida spp., and T. vaginalis (104).

sect2.title: Haemophilus ducreyi (Also See Chapter 37)
sect2.para: If infection withH. ducreyi is suspected, material from the base of the ulcer is collected and held at room temperature until it can be processed. One swab is used to prepare a smear for Gram staining. The presence of many small, pleomorphic Gram-negative bacilli and coccobacilli arranged in chains and groups (“school of fish”) suggests H. ducreyi, but this is rarely seen. Recovery of the organisms requires culture using an enriched medium, such as GC agar, but ulcer disease is much better diagnosed with molecular methods.

sect2.title: Actinomyces spp. (Also See Chapter 55)
sect2.para: Actinomyces spp., such as Actinomyces israelii, may cause pelvic inflammatory disease in women who use intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUDs). An IUD submitted for culture should be placed in a sterile liquid medium (preferably reduced, such as thioglycolate) and vortexed, and the liquid medium should be used to inoculate aerobic and anaerobic culture media. Inflammatory debris and tissue attached to the IUD should be removed and cultured aerobically and anaerobically. Anaerobic cultures should be incubated for 10 to 14 days to recover Actinomyces spp. Actinomyces spp. produce small knots of intertwined bacterial filaments called grains or granules, which may be 1 mm or more in diameter. These grains should be crushed on a slide for Gram staining and transferred to medium for culture. The presence of branching Gram-positive filaments suggests Actinomyces spp. in this clinical setting, and culture confirms the diagnosis.

sect2.title: Screening for Group B Streptococcus
sect2.para: Pregnant women colonized vaginally or rectally with group B streptococci prior to delivery are at increased risk of infecting their newborns during delivery. Current recommendations are to collect vaginal and rectal swabs in transport medium (Amies or Stuart’s) at 36 0/7 to 37 6/7 weeks of gestation for culture in a single enrichment broth, such as LIM broth (105, 106). NAATs for group B Streptococcus with comparable or improved sensitivity are commercially available but still require at least 18 h of incubation in enrichment broth before testing for optimal sensitivity (107).

sect1.title: Lower Respiratory Tract
sect1.para: Specimens from the lower respiratory tract are submitted to determine the etiology of airway disease, including tracheobronchitis, pneumonia, lung abscess, and empyema (108). Usual specimens submitted consist of sputum (expectorated and induced); endotracheal tube aspirates; bronchial brushings, washes, or alveolar lavages (collected blindly or during bronchoscopy); and pleural fluid. Specimens should be transported to the laboratory promptly and processed without delay to preserve viability of fastidious organisms such as S. pneumoniae. If delays are unavoidable, specimens should be refrigerated.

Lower respiratory tract secretions produced in the context of infection usually contain acute inflammatory cells such as PMNs. To prevent bacterial workup and reporting of the oropharyngeal microbiota rather than microbes from lower airway secretions, sputum specimens should be assessed for SECs (109, 110). Increased numbers of SECs (generally defined as ≥25 per 10× objective microscopic field) indicate gross contamination with oropharyngeal contents, and these specimens are rejected. Other screening methods take into account the relative amounts of PMNs and SECs, and specimens are accepted or rejected based on the ratio of inflammation to contamination. These screening methods should be used cautiously for immunocompromised patients (111). Respiratory tract specimens for the detection of M. tuberculosis should not be screened for adequacy, as all specimens representing the lower respiratory tract are considered acceptable for the detection of this microorganism (112). Cultures of respiratory tract material should include a selective Gram-negative medium, such as MacConkey agar, sheep blood agar, or colistin-nalidixic acid agar, and chocolate agar for the detection of Haemophilus spp. Culture plates should be incubated at 35°C in 3 to 5% CO2 for 48 h. Diagnosis of legionellosis can be accomplished by culture, urine antigen detection, or NAAT. A multiplex PCR panel for the detection of 26 respiratory pathogens, including Legionella pneumophilia, using sputum, endotracheal aspirates, or bronchial alveolar lavage (BAL) specimens is commercially available (FilmArray Pneumonia panel; BioFire Diagnostics, Salt Lake City, UT) (113).

sect2.title: Special Considerations for Lower Respiratory Tract Specimens

sect3.title: Specimens Collected during Bronchoscopy
sect3.para: Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and protected specimen brush (PSB) specimens from patients with suspected pneumonia should be cultured quantitatively to evaluate the significance of potential pathogens recovered (114). To collect bronchial brush specimens, the brush should be placed in 1 ml of sterile nonbacteriostatic saline or lactated Ringer’s solution, which is less inhibitory to Legionella species. All specimens should be processed rapidly upon receipt in the microbiology laboratory. In the laboratory, the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and PSB specimens are agitated on a vortex mixer, a smear is prepared by cytocentrifugation for Gram staining, and 0.01 ml of specimen is inoculated to appropriate media by using a pipette or calibrated loop. If anaerobes are to be cultured (from PSB specimens only), chopped meat or anaerobic thioglycolate medium can be used. Both PMNs and SECs should be quantitated via the Gram stain to report on the quality of the specimen received for culture, but the results should not be used as rejection criteria.

sect3.title: Specimens from Patients with Cystic Fibrosis (Also See Chapter 46)
sect3.para: Respiratory samples from cystic fibrosis patients require additional media to detect the important pathogens unique to these patients (115). Specimens submitted for culture include sputum, aspirates, or deep throat swabs. Additional selective media include Burkholderia cepacia selective agar or oxidative-fermentative polymyxin B-bacitracin-lactose agar for recovery of Burkholderia cepacia complex, mannitol salt agar or S. aureus chromogenic agar for enhanced recovery of S. aureus, and inhibitory mold agar for enhanced recovery of filamentous fungi (116, 117). B. cepacia selective agar can also be used for the recovery of rapidly growing mycobacteria from these patients (118).

sect1.title: Upper Respiratory Tract
sect1.para: Upper respiratory tract specimens include the external nares (for MRSA detection), nasopharynx, throat, oral ulcerations, and inflammatory material from the nasal sinuses. Although few serious diseases involve these areas, many pathogens colonize or persist in these sites while causing symptomatic infection in deeper, less accessible sites (119). Detection of group A Streptococcus (GAS) to diagnose pharyngitis is the most common test ordered for specimens from the upper respiratory tract. Throat swabs for detection of GAS only can be sent dry, without transport medium. Optimal media to recover GAS are horse and sheep blood agar and selective streptococcal agar, which makes the organism easier to visualize by inhibiting accompanying members of the oral microbiota but may delay the appearance of colonies of S. pyogenes. Due to the insensitivity of GAS rapid antigen testing and the risk of poststreptococcal sequelae, pediatric patients with a negative GAS antigen test should also have a culture performed (120). Two throat swabs should be collected to allow culture if necessary. If only one swab is received, the culture should be inoculated first. Adult patients do not require culture backup following negative rapid antigen testing (120). Rapid NAAT tests for GAS pharyngitis that can be performed at the point of care with results in approximately 15 min are available (121). These rapid molecular tests have shown sensitivities equivalent to that of reference culture, ≥97%, and eliminate the need for backup testing in the event of negative results.

Group C and G streptococci,Fusobacterium necrophorum, Arcanobacterium haemolyticum, N. gonorrhoeae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, mycoplasmas, and chlamydiae may also occasionally cause pharyngitis. Anaerobic culture from throat swabs is necessary for the recovery of F. necrophorum. A standard swab is sufficient and should be placed in a transport carrier containing Amies or modified Stuart’s medium (122). NAATs are the test of choice for detection of N. gonorrhoeae in the throat, due to their enhanced sensitivity.

Nasopharyngeal specimens are generally submitted only for detection of the causative agents of pertussis or whooping cough. NAAT is the most sensitive method for detectingB. pertussis and Bordetella parapertussis, and a number of FDA-approved assays are commercially available (123). For recovery of Bordetella spp., a small-tipped Dacron or rayon swab is optimal, as cotton-tipped or calcium-alginate swabs may be toxic to the organism. The sensitivity of culture decreases dramatically after the first 2 weeks of illness, and it is recommended primarily when there is a suspicion of a pertussis outbreak (124).

Inflammatory material from the nasal sinuses should be cultured to detect the etiologies of sinusitis. Nearly all cases of bacterial sinusitis follow a primary upper respiratory tract viral infection. Bacteria are trapped in the sinus as a result of damage to the epithelial lining cells of the sinus, and inflammation and swelling narrow or close the nasal ostium, preventing normal drainage (125). Specimens collected during endoscopic procedures by physicians specializing in otorhinolaryngology are optimal, since they are taken directly from the infected sinus, avoiding contamination by normal members of the microbiota in the nasal passages. Aspirates, washes, scrapings or debridement material, and biopsy material should be kept moist and sent in a sterile container to the laboratory. Aerobic culture is needed in all cases; anaerobic transport and culture may be needed in cases of chronic sinusitis. Although swabs obtained with endoscopic guidance correlate well with aspirates for recovery of bacteria, they do a poor job of recovering fungi, which have been implicated as etiological agents of chronic sinusitis (126).

sect1.title: Tissue Biopsy Samples
sect1.para: Tissue from a sterile site is usually obtained during a surgical procedure and should be of a sufficient volume for all possible tests, including histopathology and various microbiological studies. A 1-cm3 piece or 1 g of tissue should suffice for any microbiology requests. This is difficult with fine-needle aspirates and biopsy samples, which usually are minuscule. Tissue should be transported in a sterile container as rapidly as possible to prevent drying. To maintain moisture, very small pieces of tissue can be placed on a square of sterile gauze saturated with sterile, nonbacteriostatic saline. If anaerobic cultures are requested, the tissue should be transported in an anaerobic transport tube or vial, many of which maintain anaerobes extremely well even during overnight shipping. Larger pieces of tissue (>1 cm3) maintain a reduced atmosphere in spite of brief aerobic transport. Oxygen-free transport may not be necessary in this circumstance, and the absence of anaerobic transport should not disqualify large pieces of tissue from anaerobic culture. Once the tissue is received in the laboratory, any frankly infected portions of tissue should be selected prior to grinding (or mincing for fungal cultures); Gram staining and culture should be performed.

Some agents of bacterial infections in tissue cannot be cultivatedin vitro using standard microbiological media. These infections include syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella (Calymmatobacterium) granulomatis, rat bite fever, caused by Spirillum minus, and others. The organisms may be visualized by histopathologic stains. Newer molecular technologies are proving to be most reliable, especially for organisms causing genital ulcer disease and those found in biofilms (127, 128). The use of DNA sequencing to identify bacteria seen in tissue sections by histology, including Tropheryma whipplei, Coxiella burnetii, and Bartonella henselae, is gaining favor (41).

Tissue from traumatic wound or burn injury may be submitted for quantitative culture, with results of ≥105 CFU/g being used to predict the likelihood of the development of wound-related sepsis (129). Full-thickness punch biopsy samples should be collected for this process, and a detailed procedure can be found in the Clinical Microbiology Procedures Handbook (3). Limitations include the lack of reproducible results and the low predictive value compared to histologic examination of tissue (130).

sect1.title: Bone Marrow Transport and Culture
sect1.para: Although bone marrow aspirate cultures may be helpful in identifying disseminated fungal and mycobacterial diseases, they are unlikely to assist in the identification of most bacterial diseases (131, 132). It is also a routine procedure in some transplant centers to submit harvested bone marrow aspirates in either lysis centrifugation (Isolator) tubes or sterile containers for bacterial culture. Bone marrow aspirates received in a sterile container should be transferred to a blood culture bottle and incubated in the automated blood culture instrument. If bone marrow culture is performed, direct Gram staining of bone marrow aspirates is not helpful and should not be a routine component of bacterial culture.

sect1.title: Lymph Nodes
sect1.para: Aspirates and biopsy samples from lymph nodes are usually sent to the laboratory for detection of nonbacterial infectious agents. However, studies of lymph nodes from patients with mycobacterial disease, cat scratch disease, plague, brucellosis, or tularemia can be fruitful. Initial handling of the tissue itself and of the culture plates, whether showing growth or not, should be done with extreme care, and all biosafety practices should be employed. Plates should be taped to prevent accidental opening.

sect1.title: Necrotizing Fasciitis
sect1.para: Necrotizing fasciitis and gas gangrene (myonecrosis) are medical emergencies requiring immediate diagnosis and therapy that may include antimicrobials and surgical debridement (133). Necrotizing fasciitis and gas gangrene are most commonly caused by toxin-producing Streptococcus pyogenes, other beta-hemolytic streptococci, S. aureus, Clostridium spp., and mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacteria (133, 134). Gram-stained smears of intraoperative tissue, fascia, muscle, and/or fluid are particularly helpful and show necrotic cell debris, rare or few PMNs (because of cell lysis), and the causative bacteria, which should be confirmed by culture.

sect1.title: Cellulitis
sect1.para: Several studies have shown that aspirates from the leading edge of areas of cellulitis are not clinically useful. Injection of nonbacteriostatic saline and subsequent aspiration may be necessary to obtain enough material to culture (135). Under the best of conditions, these specimens are unlikely to be positive and so they are not recommended. Blood cultures from patients with cellulitis also are unlikely to be positive (134). Tissue biopsy may be required if microbiological testing is deemed crucial for a rapidly progressing lesion.

sect1.title: Urinary Tract
sect1.para: Diseases of the urinary tract include prostatitis, urethral syndrome, cystitis, and pyelonephritis. Urine, prostatic secretions, or urethral specimens are needed to diagnose these diseases. Urine culture is the most common test performed by most microbiology laboratories. However, contamination of urine, defined as growth of commensal skin, vaginal, or fecal microbiota in the absence of true urinary tract infection (UTI), is detected in approximately 5 to 40% of cultures. There is ongoing controversy regarding how urine should be collected to minimize contamination, but traditional skin cleansing prior to collection of midstream urine is still recommended, and provision of written instructions on proper collection can help reduce contamination rates (136). Improper urine specimen collection, storage, and transport to the laboratory will result in inaccurate and misleading culture results. Therefore, urine specimens should be processed within 30 min of collection, refrigerated for no more than 24 h if delay is expected, or placed in transport tubes containing boric acid at room temperature for 24 h (4).

Chronic indwelling urinary catheters, percutaneous nephrostomy tubes, and ileal conduits are increasingly encountered in patients and present unique challenges in collection of specimens while avoiding colonizing flora. Culture from indwelling catheters is discouraged, but if it is necessary, the specimen should be taken from the sampling port of a newly inserted catheter (4). Similarly, collection of specimens from ileal conduits and nephrostomy tubes is discouraged, as they are chronically colonized with bacteria (4).

The standard for quantitative bacterial culture of urine is the inoculation of 0.01 or 0.001 ml of specimen using a calibrated pipette or a plastic or wire loop to appropriate media, usually sheep blood and MacConkey agars. If a loop is used, it should be dipped vertically into the well-mixed urine, just far enough to cover the loop. Prior to plate inoculation, it is necessary to ensure that a film of urine fills the loop with no bubbles to alter the calibrated volume. The specimen should be spread over the surface of the agar plate by streaking from top to bottom in a vertical line and again from top to bottom perpendicular to this line in a back-and-forth fashion.

sect1.title: Wounds
sect1.para: Superficial wound specimens are frequently submitted on swabs and often grow multiple organisms, including members of the commensal microbiota, which makes interpretation and treatment confusing for physicians. While superficial swabs are easy to collect, they should be discouraged. If a swab must be used, a flocked swab and transport medium system should be requested (22–25). A meta-analysis examining the usefulness of lower-extremity swabs compared to deeper cultures found the sensitivity of swabs to be only 49% and the specificity to be 62%, with a positive likelihood ratio of 1.1 and a negative likelihood ratio of 0.67 (137). In general, tissue specimens obtained by biopsy, ulcer curettage, or aspiration are preferred (138). If a transport system is not used, the specimens should be transferred to a sterile container and transported to the laboratory within 2 h at room temperature to prevent loss of fastidious organisms and prevent overgrowth of contaminating species.

It is helpful to perform a Gram stain on all wound specimens to interpret the culture. The presence of a predominant bacterial morphotype(s), acute inflammatory cells (PMNs), intracellular bacteria, and cell necrosis suggest a good-quality specimen (139). Excessive numbers of SECs suggest contamination with members of the cutaneous microbiota. It is acceptable to limit workup of bacterial isolates when the specimen shows contamination.
